questions.ocrQuestion:
At very low temperatures the heat capacity of crystals is equal to \( C=a T^{3} \), where ' \( \mathrm{a} \) ' is a constant . The entropy of a crystal as a function of temperature in this temperature interval is
(a) \( 3 a T+ \) constant
(b) \( 3 a T^{3} \)
(c) \( \frac{a T^{3}}{3}+ \) constant
(d) \( \frac{a T^{3}}{3} \)
questions.onlyq_text: At very low temperatures the heat capacity of crystals is equal to \( C=a T^{3} \), where ' \( \mathrm{a} \) ' is a constant . The entropy of a crystal as a function of temperature in this temperature interval is

solutions.sol_html: \( \begin{array}{l}C=\frac{d Q}{d T} \quad(\therefore C=\text { Heat Capacity) } \\ \Rightarrow d Q=c d T \\ S=\int \frac{d Q}{T}=\int c \frac{d T}{T} \\ =a \int T^{2} d T \\ S=\frac{a T^{3}}{3}+c \\\end{array} \)

questions.sub_topic_name: THE ENTROPY AND SECOND LAW OF THERMODYNAMICS
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The value of entropy at absolute zero of temperature would be
[JAM 2005]
(a) Zero for all the materials.
(b) Finite for all the materials.
(c) Zero for some materials and non-zero for others.
(d) Unpredictable for any material.
questions.onlyq_text: The value of entropy at absolute zero of temperature would be[JAM 2005]

options.option: (c) Zero for some materials and non-zero for others.

solutions.sol_html: Sol. According to the third law of thermodynamics - \"The entropy of any system vanishes at the absolute zero temperature\"\[\lim _{\mathrm{T} \rightarrow 0} \mathrm{~S}=0\]And according to Nernst's heat theorem: \"Any entropy changes in an isotherm at reversible process approach zero as the temperature approaches zero\".\[\lim _{\mathrm{T} \rightarrow 0} \Delta \mathrm{S}=0\]For an example, in crystal of \( \mathrm{CO} \) has finite entropy at absolute zero temperature.

questions.ocrQuestion:

The entropy of a mole of aluminium at such temperature is given by the formula is
[JAM 2007]
(a) \( a T+\frac{b}{3} T^{3}+c \), where \( c>0 \) is a constant.
(b) \( \frac{a T}{2}+\frac{b}{4} T^{3}+c \), where \( c>0 \) is a constant
(c) \( a T+\frac{b}{3} T^{3} \)
(d) \( \frac{a T}{2}+\frac{b}{4} T^{3} \)

The entropy of a mole of aluminium at such temperature is given by the formula is[JAM 2007]

options.option: (a) \( a T+\frac{b}{3} T^{3}+c \), where \( c>0 \) is a constant.
(b) \( \frac{a T}{2}+\frac{b}{4} T^{3}+c \), where \( c>0 \) is a constant

questions.ocrQuestion:
The specific heat at constant volume of the electrons in a metal \( C_{V}=\alpha \) T where ' \( T \) ' is the temperature and \( \alpha \) is a constant . The specific entropy is given by
[IISc 2012]
(a) \( k_{B} \)
(b) \( \sqrt{k_{B} \alpha T} \)
(c) \( \alpha T \)
(d) \( \frac{\alpha^{2} T^{2}}{k_{B}} \)
questions.onlyq_text: The specific heat at constant volume of the electrons in a metal \( C_{V}=\alpha \) T where ' \( T \) ' is the temperature and \( \alpha \) is a constant . The specific entropy is given by[IISc 2012]

solutions.sol_html: Given \( \quad C_{v}=\alpha T \)we know, \( \quad C_{v}=\frac{1}{n}\left(\frac{\partial Q}{\partial T}\right)_{v} \) and \( d Q=T d s \)\[\begin{array}{l}\Rightarrow C_{v}=\frac{1}{n} T\left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}\right)_{v} \\\Rightarrow \alpha T=\frac{T}{n}\left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}\right)_{v}\end{array}\]for specific entropy\[\begin{aligned}\int d s & =\int \alpha d T \\s & =\alpha T\end{aligned}\]

questions.ocrQuestion:
In a cyrogenic experiment, heat is supplied to a sample at a constant rate of 0.01 watts. The entropy of the sample increases with time as shown in the table as
\begin{tabular}{lllllll} 
Time & \( : \) & 400 & 600 & 800 & 1000 & \( (\mathrm{see}) \) \\
Entropy & \( : \) & 3.00 & 3.20 & 3.40 & 3.60 & \( (\mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K}) \)
\end{tabular}

The temperature of the sample is
(a) \( 10 \mathrm{~K} \)
(b) \( 12 \mathrm{~K} \)
(c) \( 8 \mathrm{~K} \)
(d) \( 9 \mathrm{~K} \)
questions.onlyq_text: In a cyrogenic experiment, heat is supplied to a sample at a constant rate of 0.01 watts. The entropy of the sample increases with time as shown in the table as\begin{array}{lllllll} Time & : & 400 & 600 & 800 & 1000 & (\mathrm{see}) \\Entropy & : & 3.00 & 3.20 & 3.40 & 3.60 & (\mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K}) \end{array}The temperature of the sample is

solutions.sol_html: Power \( (P)=0.01 \) wattsfrom the dato given\[\frac{\Delta s}{\Delta t}=\frac{0.20}{200} \frac{\mathrm{J}}{\mathrm{ksec}}\]Now \( P=\frac{d Q}{d t}=T \frac{d s}{d t} \)\[\begin{aligned}\Rightarrow 0.01 & =T \times \frac{0.20}{200} \\\Rightarrow \quad T & =200 \times \frac{0.01}{0.20} \mathrm{~K} \\\Rightarrow T & =10 \mathrm{~K}\end{aligned}\]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The molar specific heat of a gas as given from the kinetic theory is \( \frac{5}{2} R \). If it is not specified whether it is \( C_{p} \) or \( C_{v} \), one could conclude that the molecules of the gas
(A) are definitely monatomic
(B) are definitely rigid diatomic
(C) are definitely non-rigid diatomic
(D) can be monatomic or rigid diatomic
questions.onlyq_text: The molar specific heat of a gas as given from the kinetic theory is \( \frac{5}{2} R \). If it is not specified whether it is \( C_{p} \) or \( C_{v} \), one could conclude that the molecules of the gas

options.option: (D) can be monatomic or rigid diatomic

solutions.sol_html: Sol. We know, the specific heat at constant volume of a gas is given by\[\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{dT}} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{u}}\right)_{\mathrm{V}}\]and \( \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}-\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}=\mathrm{R} \)where, \( \overrightarrow{\mathrm{u}} \) is the average energy.According to the kinetic theory of gas,\( \overrightarrow{\mathrm{u}}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{RT} \) for monoatomic gas.\( \overrightarrow{\mathrm{u}}=\frac{6}{2} \mathrm{RT}=3 \mathrm{RT} \)\( \overrightarrow{\mathrm{u}}=\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{RT} \)for non rigid diatomic gas.for rigid diatomic gas.For monoatomic,\[\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{R} \text { and } \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}=\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{R}\]For rigid diatomic,\[\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}=\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{R} \text { and } \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}=\frac{7}{2} \mathrm{R}\]

questions.sub_topic_name: THE ENTROPY AND SECOND LAW OF THERMODYNAMICS
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.concept_html:
There are 4 laws to thermodynamics:

  • Zeroth law of thermodynamics - If two thermodynamic systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each 
  • The first law of thermodynamics - Energy can neither be created nor destroyed. It can only change forms. In any process, the total energy of the universe remains the same. For a thermodynamic cycle, the net heat supplied to the system equals the net work done by the system.

\[ \delta Q=\Delta U+\delta W \]

  • The second law of thermodynamics - The entropy of an isolated system not in equilibrium will tend to increase over time, approaching a maximum value at equilibrium.

\[ \Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {Total }}=\Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {System }}+\Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {surrounding }} \]

  • The second law of thermodynamic actually deals with the quality of the energy. As per the second law of thermodynamic whenever low-grade energy transfer from one state to another state some randomness get associated with the energy and the quality of energy get degraded.
  • The second law of thermodynamics introduces the concept of entropy.
  • Third law of thermodynamics - As the temperature approaches absolute zero, the entropy of a systemapproaches a constant minimum.

\[ \Delta \mathbf{S}_{\mathrm{T}=0 \mathrm{~K}}=0 \]
questions.ocrQuestion:
The second law of thermodynamics implies:
1. whole of the heat can be converted into mechanical energy.
2. no heat engine can have \(100 \%\) efficiency.
3. same heat engines working in reversible process can have \(100 \%\) efficiency.
4. a refrigerator can reduce the temperature to absolute zero.
questions.onlyq_text: The second law of thermodynamics implies:

options.option: 1. whole of the heat can be converted into mechanical energy.
2. no heat engine can have \(100 \%\) efficiency.
3. same heat engines working in reversible process can have \(100 \%\) efficiency.
4. a refrigerator can reduce the temperature to absolute zero.

solutions.sol_html:
The correct answer is no heat engine can have \(\mathbf{1 0 0} \%\) efficiency.

  • The second law of thermodynamic centers around the concept of efficiency in heat engines and the natural flow of heat towards colder regions.
  • In its simplest form, it stands against the possibility of perpetual motion machines.
  • The second law suggests that no heat engine can convert \(100 \%\) of its input heat energy \((\mathrm{QH})\) into work (W).
  • There is always some waste heat (QC) that is given off to a colder reservoir.
  • The efficiency of a heat engine is defined by 1 - (QC/QH), and thus it must always be less than \(100 \%\).
  • This conclusion is important because it limits what we can achieve with heat engines like those used in power plants, cars, and various machines.
  •  It means that there is always an unavoidable loss of energy, which is why energy saving measures are important.

questions.sub_topic_name: THE ENTROPY AND SECOND LAW OF THERMODYNAMICS
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.concept_html:
• The efficiency of a heat engine is defined as the ratio of the net work done by the engine in one cycle to the amount of heat absorbed by the working substance from the source.
  • The efficiency of a heat engine is given by: \(\eta=1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}\) (where \(Q_{2}\) is heat reject and \(Q_{1}\) is the heat absorbed)
  • The efficiency of a heat engine is always less than \(100 \%\).
  • When \(Q=0, \boldsymbol{\eta}=\mathbf{1}\) or \(\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}\)

\[ \eta=1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}} \]

  •  But any working substance in a cycle cannot convert all the heat extracted from the source into work. It has to reject some amount of heat to the sink. That is why the efficiency of a heat engine is always less than the unity.
  • This is applicable to a refrigerator. The working substance can absorb heat from the cold body only if work is done on it. If no external work is done, the refrigerator will not work.
  •  The Second Law of Thermodynamics state that: "It is impossible for a self-acting machine, unaided by any external agency, to transfer heat from a body to another a higher temperature"
